Introduction

Hypernatremia is an electrolyte disorder characterized by a serum sodium (Na+) concentration >145 mEq/L due to loss of water (ie, dehydration) or gain of sodium.  Although the absolute amount of sodium in the body may be normal, low, or high, hypernatremia always indicates a relative deficit of total body free water (TBFW) relative to total body sodium (TBNa+).  This is in contrast to hyponatremia (discussed in a separate article), where there is an excess of TBFW relative to TBNa⁺.

Pathophysiology



Na+ is the primary extracellular cation and plays a critical role in maintaining extracellular fluid volume and osmolality.  The body tightly regulates serum Na+ concentration through mechanisms involving the following organs:

Hypothalamus



The hypothalamus contains osmoreceptors that, when stimulated by increased serum osmolality, trigger thirst.  This prompts increased fluid intake to help maintain proper sodium concentration.

Posterior pituitary gland



The posterior pituitary gland releases antidiuretic hormone (ADH), also known as arginine vasopressin (AVP), in response to increased serum osmolality or decreased effective circulating volume.

Kidneys



In response to ADH, the collecting ducts increase water reabsorption through aquaporin channels.



Hypernatremia occurs when there is a disruption in one or more of these regulatory mechanisms, leading to a relative excess of sodium compared to water.  Most cases are due to free water loss, although hypernatremia may also result from an excess sodium load.  Free water loss (ie, dehydration) should be distinguished from the loss of both water and sodium (ie, hypovolemia).  Although hypovolemia is typically accompanied by hyponatremia (due to comparable sodium and water losses), hypernatremia can occasionally be seen in volume-depleted patients when there is a greater loss of water relative to sodium.

Presentation



Hypernatremia usually does not develop unless the thirst mechanism is impaired.  Even with inadequate ADH action, individuals with intact thirst can usually drink enough water to maintain normal serum sodium.  This highlights why hypernatremia is more prevalent in high-risk groups such as:



  • Elderly patients, particularly those with cognitive impairment
  • Patients with altered mental status
  • Individuals without free access to water (eg, intubated patients in the intensive care unit)


These groups may have a blunted thirst response or limited ability to communicate their need for water.



Symptoms primarily result from cellular dehydration and neuronal shrinkage, and their severity is influenced by both the degree of hypernatremia and the rapidity of onset.  Chronic hypernatremia is often better tolerated due to the brain's ability to adapt to slow changes in serum osmolality.  Common symptoms include extreme thirst (if the thirst mechanism is intact), encephalopathy ranging from mild confusion to coma, muscle weakness, seizures, and focal neurologic deficits.

Etiologies



Hypernatremia can result from various causes, broadly categorized as follows:

Water losses



  • Insensible losses
    • Fever:  Elevated body temperature increases water loss through sweating and increased respiratory rate.
    • Burns:  Large surface area burns can lead to significant water loss through damaged skin.
    • Hyperthermia:  Excess heat exposure increases sweating and water loss.
  • Renal losses
    • Water diuresis:  AVP deficiency (formerly diabetes insipidus) leads to impaired renal water reabsorption.
    • Osmotic diuresis:  Increased concentrations of substances such as glucose (in uncontrolled diabetes mellitus) or urea (in severe azotemia) pull water into the urine, increasing water loss (ie, solute diuresis).
  • Gastrointestinal losses
    • Osmotic diarrhea:  Unabsorbed substances (eg, lactulose, sorbitol) in the intestines can increase stool water loss.  This is unique from other causes of diarrhea accompanied by solute loss (ie, hyponatremia).
    • Vomiting:  Vomiting can lead to significant loss of electrolyte-rich fluid, particularly if prolonged and not compensated by increased water intake.  However, vomiting more often is accompanied with solute loss (ie, hyponatremia).

Inadequate water intake



  • Impaired thirst mechanism
    • Older, frail adults and those with impaired cognition can have a diminished sense of thirst, leading to reduced water intake.
  • Limited access to water
    • Individuals who are bedridden without assistance or who participate in prolonged outdoor activities without water supply are at increased risk.

Excessive sodium intake



  • Iatrogenic
    • Excess hypertonic saline administration can lead to hypernatremia if not carefully monitored.
    • Excess ingestion of sodium bicarbonate, such as during treatment of metabolic acidosis in chronic kidney disease, can cause hypernatremia.


These etiologies may lead to hypernatremia individually or in combination, ultimately reflecting an imbalance between water and sodium.

Evaluation



The cause of hypernatremia is often apparent from the clinical presentation.  If needed, volume status should be assessed (Na+ is the primary determinant of intravascular volume) via physical examination (eg, assessment of jugular vein pressure, skin turgor, and orthostatic vital signs).  Additional clarity may be obtained by measuring urine sodium and osmolality (

figure 1
):



  • Hypovolemic (↓↓TBFW, ↓TBNa+)

    • Urine sodium ≥20 mEq/L:  Renal water and Na+ loss (eg, diuresis, natriuresis)
    • Urine sodium <20 mEq/L:  Nonrenal water and Na+ loss (eg, burns, diarrhea)
  • Euvolemic (↓TBFW, ↔TBNa+)
    • Urine osmolality <300 mOsm/kg:  Renal water loss (eg, AVP deficiency)
    • Urine osmolality ≥600 mOsm/kg:  Nonrenal water loss (eg, insensible losses)
  • Hypervolemic (↑TBFW, ↑↑TBNa+)
    • Urine ≥40 mEq/L:  Na+ gain (eg, iatrogenic, primary hyperaldosteronism)


Further evaluation depends on the clinical picture.  Polyuria is highly suggestive of an AVP disorder, which requires further testing (eg, water deprivation test, AVP challenge), described in a separate article.

Management



Treating hypernatremia involves addressing the free water deficit while accounting for volume status.  Free water can be administered either orally (or via a feeding tube) or intravenously.  When given intravenously, free water is given as a hypotonic solution with either 5% dextrose in water (D5W) (the dextrose prevents cell hemolysis) or 0.45% (half normal) saline.  D5W (ie, 0 mEq/L sodium) will dilute serum sodium more than an equal volume of 0.45% saline (ie, 77 mEq/L sodium), resulting in faster correction of hypernatremia.  However, volume status also guides the choice of fluids:



  • Euvolemic or hypervolemic patients with hypernatremia need only free water (eg, D5W is preferred).
  • Hypovolemic patients benefit from the volume-expanding effect of sodium, in addition to the free water (eg, 0.45% saline is often used).


The free water deficit can be estimated using a formula (TBFW × [(current Na⁺ / 140) – 1], where TBFW is estimated as 0.6 × body weight (kg) for men and 0.5 × body weight (kg) for women).  This deficit should be corrected over 24 hours.  Optimal rates of infusion can be estimated from the combination of the total free water deficit and the sodium concentration of the solution being infused.  Further adjustments can be made based on changes in clinical response, with adjustments for patients with high insensible losses.



Compared to hyponatremia management (where saline rapidly increases extracellular osmolality), hypernatremia should be corrected more aggressively (slow correction may be associated with worse outcomes).  This is because free water immediately equilibrates evenly throughout all compartments, leading to less osmotic stress on neurons.

Summary



Hypernatremia (serum sodium >145 mEq/L) reflects an imbalance between total body water and sodium content.  It results from various causes including excessive water loss, insufficient water intake, or, rarely, an increase in sodium intake.  The body's primary defense against hypernatremia is the thirst mechanism, which is crucial for individuals with intact cognition and access to water.  Effective management is based on an assessment of the underlying etiology and the patient's volume status, with careful correction of the free water deficit.  Unlike in cases of chronic hyponatremia, rapid correction of hypernatremia is generally well tolerated.
